maml:description.maml:para: Upload artifact to GRR.
Upload artifact to GRR.

maml:Description.maml:para: Path to artifact file.
GRR credentials to use.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Return plain JSON instead of parsed JSON object.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Path to artifact file.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
GRR credentials to use.
Return plain JSON instead of parsed JSON object.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Upload artifact "DNSNameServer" to GRR. See https://github.com/ForensicArtifacts/artifacts for more information about artifact definition.

Upload artifact "OutlookFiles" to GRR. See https://github.com/ForensicArtifacts/artifacts for more information about artifact definition. No credentials parameter is used because `$GRRCredential` is set before running the command.

maml:description.maml:para: Decode a base64 encoded string. This function is used also inside fetching results when only payload should be returned.
Some flows return an base64 encoded string in the payload. Use this function to convert it.

maml:Description.maml:para: Base64 encoded string to decode.
Encoding to use. Unicode or UTF8.
Base64 encoded string to decode.
Encoding to use. Unicode or UTF8.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Convert the collected sha256 hash (hash_entry e.g. from file finder flow) to the corresponding hex representation. The payload from GRR is base64 encoded, therefore Convertfrom-Base64 provides the needed step in between. For a hash conversion the use of "-Encoding Unicode" is needed.

Convert the collected sha256 hash (hash_entry e.g. from file finder flow) to the corresponding hex representation. The payload from GRR is base64 encoded, therefore Convertfrom-Base64 provides the needed step in between.
Analyse return values from a hunt and filter them for specific payload values.

maml:description.maml:para: Encodes a string into base64.
This function is used inside other functions. Not used directly for day to day work.
Encodes a string into base64.

maml:Description.maml:para: String to convert to base64.
Encoding type - use `[Text.Encoding]::...` to specify the encoding.
`[Text.Encoding]::ASCII` is used by default.
Encoding type - use `[Text.Encoding]::...` to specify the encoding.
`[Text.Encoding]::ASCII` is used by default.
String to convert to base64.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Convert the string to base64.

maml:description.maml:para: Use the GRR search function to search for clients. The function returns only the computername or the whole GRR object.
Find GRR clients based on the given search string.

maml:Description.maml:para: Search string with the needed prefix, e.g. label: or host:...
GRR credentials.
Show only the computername.
Show the response as JSON instead of parsed object.
GRR credentials.
Show only the computername.
Search string with the needed prefix, e.g. label: or host:...
Show the response as JSON instead of parsed object.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Find GRR clients based on keywords. Use the available prefixes, e.g. "label:" or "host:" to limit the search results.
Find GRR clients based on keywords. Use the available prefixes, e.g. "label:" or "host:" to limit the search results. Use `-OnlyComputerName` to only display the host names.
Find GRR clients where the given user was logged in. Use `-OnlyComputerName` to only display the host names.
Find GRR clients with the OS "darwin" (MacOS). Use `-OnlyComputerName` to only display the host names.

maml:description.maml:para: Search for clients with a given label.
{{Fill in the Description}}

maml:Description.maml:para: Label to search for.
GRR credentials.
Show only the computername.
Return plain JSON instead of parsed JSON object.
GRR credentials.
Show only the computername.
Label to search for.
Return plain JSON instead of parsed JSON object.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Search for clients with a specific label.
Search for clients with a specific label and show only the host names.

maml:description.maml:para: Get a list of all GRR artifacts.
Get the list of available artifacts. The return object is a PowerShell object which is easily to filter with common PowerShell cmdlets. See example.

maml:Description.maml:para: GRR credentials.
Return only plain JSON instead of converted JSON objects.
GRR credentials.
Return only plain JSON instead of converted JSON objects.

dev:remarks.maml:para: List all artifacts.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> $osx = Get-GRRArtifact -Credential $cred | ? {$_.name -match "osx"} | select name, description, iscustom PS C:\> $osx
Name Description IsCustom ---- ----------- -------- OSXSPHardwareDataType Mac OS X system profiler. False OSXServices Running services from the Max OS X service management framework. False OSXUsers Users directories in /Users False

command:example.maml:title: Example 3
Example 4

dev:remarks.maml:para: List all custom artifacts.

maml:description.maml:para: Get client approval identified by the given filters.

Get client approval identified by approval id and client id or list client approvals based on the available filters. Use the ComputerName filter and let PowerGRR translate this into the needed client id.
Get only the state of a client approval and use this in a loop to wait until the approval is valid and you can continue with the desired actions.

maml:Description.maml:para: Approval id from New-GRRClientApproval.
ComputerName for which an approval was requested.
GRR credentials.
Return only the state of the approval. Useful for loops.
Return only plain JSON instead of converted JSON objects.
ComputerName for which an approval was requested.
Amount of approvals to be returned.
GRR credentials.
Offset for the returned approvals.
Return only plain JSON instead of converted JSON objects.
Filter for the approval state.
Approval id from New-GRRClientApproval.
ComputerName for which an approval was requested.
Amount of approvals to be returned.
GRR credentials.
Offset for the returned approvals.
Return only the state of the approval. Useful for loops.
Return only plain JSON instead of converted JSON objects.
Filter for the approval state.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1

dev:remarks.maml:para: Return the latest approval. Use " | select -expandproperty is_valid" after the command for only returning the state.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-GRRClientApproval -Credential $cred -OnlyState -ComputerName host1 -ApprovalId approval:AAAAAAAA False

dev:remarks.maml:para: Get the client approval for the host 'host1' and the approval id 'approval:AAAAAAAA'. Use this command in a loop to wait until the approval is valid and you can continue with the desired actions.

command:example.maml:title: Example 3

dev:remarks.maml:para: Get the latest two client approvals with the state "INVALID", that means not yet approved.

maml:description.maml:para: Convert a list of computer names into the corresponding GRR client id.
Convert a list of computer names into the corresponding GRR client id and display further information about the client.

maml:Description.maml:para: Computername to search for.
GRR credentials.
Use the switch to only show the latest seen client id.
Return plain JSON instead of converted JSON.
Computername to search for.
GRR credentials.
Use the switch to only show the latest seen client id.
Return plain JSON instead of converted JSON.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Search for the client ids for the two hosts. If one host has multiple IDs (e.g. after a new installation) both are shown. See Example 2 to only show last seen hosts.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Get-GRRClientIdFromComputerName -ComputerName host1,host2 -Credential $creds -OnlyLastSeen
Node ClientId LastSeenAt OSVersion ---- -------- ---------- --------- host1 C.1111111111111111 18.05.2017 15:48:17 10.0.10586 host2 C.3333333333333333 26.06.2017 09:31:32 6.1.7601

dev:remarks.maml:para: Search for the client ids for the two hosts. If multiple client ids are found, the parameter "OnlyLastSeen" reduce the output to last seen one per each host. Compare the output to EXAMPLE 1.
Search for the client id for the two hosts and return only the client id.

maml:description.maml:para: Get important client infos.
Get important client infos.

maml:Description.maml:para: Computer name to search for.
GRR credentials.
Flag, if only the last seen client ids should be returned for the host.
Return plain JSON instead of converted JSON.
Computer name to search for.
GRR credentials.
Flag, if only the last seen client ids should be returned for the host.
Return plain JSON instead of converted JSON.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Get host information for that specific host. No `-Credential` param is needed because `$GRRCredential` was set before running the command.
Get host information for that specific host based on the pipeline input.

maml:description.maml:para: Search for a specific client id and return the computer name.
Search for a specific client id and return the computer name.

maml:Description.maml:para: Client id to search for.
GRR credentials.
Return only plain JSON instead of converted JSON objects.
Client id to search for.
GRR credentials.
Return only plain JSON instead of converted JSON objects.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-GRRComputerNameFromClientId -Credential $creds -ClientId c.1111111111111111 PS C:\> Get-GRRComputerNameFromClientId -Credential $creds -ClientId c.1111111111111111, c.2222222222222222 PS C:\> c.1111111111111111 | Get-GRRComputerNameFromClientId -Credential $cred PS C:\> c.1111111111111111,c.2222222222222222 | Get-GRRComputerNameFromClientId -Credential $cred

dev:remarks.maml:para: Returns the host name for one or multiple client ids. Use the parameter ClientId or the pipeline as input.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $ret.items.client_id | unique | Get-GRRComputerNameFromClientId -Credential $cred PS C:\> $ret.items.client_id | unique | Get-GRRComputerNameFromClientId -Credential $cred | select -ExpandProperty computername | Get-GRRClientInfo -Credential $cred | select -ExpandProperty usernames

dev:remarks.maml:para: Convert the client id's from a hunt into their corresponding computer names. In the 2nd example the computer names are then used with `Get-GRRClientInfo` and therefore the logged in users from these hosts can be found.

maml:description.maml:para: Get the current PowerGRR config.
Get the current PowerGRR config.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1
command:example.dev:code:
PS> Get-GRRConfig
ConfigFile GRRUrl GRRIgnoreCertificateErrors GRRClientCertIssuer ---------- ------ -------------------------- ------------------- ...\powergrr-config.ps1 https://grrserver.tld false (default) none (default)

dev:remarks.maml:para: Read the current config.

maml:description.maml:para: Get a list of all available flows.
List all flows and allow filtering based on category, name and doc content.

maml:Description.maml:para: GRR credentials.
Show plain JSON output.
GRR credentials.
Show plain JSON output.

dev:remarks.maml:para: List all available flows.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $ret = Get-GRRFlowDescriptor -Credential $cred PS C:\> $ret | select name

dev:remarks.maml:para: List all available flows and display all the flow names.

command:example.maml:title: Example 3
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $ret = Get-GRRFlowDescriptor -Credential $cred PS C:\> $ret | where { $_.category -match "memory"}

dev:remarks.maml:para: List all available flows from the memory category.

command:example.maml:title: Example 4
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $ret = Get-GRRFlowDescriptor -Credential $cred PS C:\> $ret | where { $_.category -match "file"} | select name

dev:remarks.maml:para: List all available flows from the file category and display only the flow names.
List all available flows where "proc" is in the flow name.

maml:description.maml:para: Get flow results for a specific client and a flow.
Get flow results for a specific client and a flow.

maml:Description.maml:para: Computername of the client.
GRR credential.
Flow id for which the results should be returned.
Return only the payload. If possible already base64 decoded.
Return plain JSON instead of converted JSON.
Computername of the client.
GRR credential.
Flow id for which the results should be returned.
Return only the payload. If possible already base64 decoded.
Return plain JSON instead of converted JSON.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $res = Get-GRRFlowResult -Credential $cred -ComputerName host -FlowId "F:11111111" PS C:\> $res.items.payload | ConvertFrom-Base64

dev:remarks.maml:para: Get the flow results and decode the base64 encoded payload. See next example for a short version to get only the payload.
Get the flow results and decode the base64 encoded payload directly.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Find last hunt id. You can use all the filtering from PowerShell. Each hunt is represented as an own PowerShell object. The disadvantage of this POST-filtering is that the command first returns every hunt. See next example to use a PRE-filtering.

Find last 5 hunt id. You can use all the filtering from PowerShell. Each hunt is represented as an own PowerShell object. The advantage of this usage is that GRR server filters the hunts on the server before returning the response.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Return latest hunt approval request.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2

dev:remarks.maml:para: Return all hunt approval requests. Use PowerShell to filter them as needed.

command:example.maml:title: Example 3

dev:remarks.maml:para: Return a specific hunt approval request and use PowerShell to get a specifc values.

command:example.maml:title: Example 4
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> PS> Get-GRRHuntApproval -Credential $cred -HuntId H:11111111 -ApprovalId approval:AAAAAAAA -OnlyState False

dev:remarks.maml:para: Return only the state of a specific hunt approval request. Use that for a loop and if approval becomes valid start the hunt directly.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $res = Get-GRRHuntResult -HuntId H:AAAAAAAA -Credential $creds PS C:\> ($res.items.payload.stat_entry.aff4path).substring(31) | sort -u PS C:\> $res.items.client_id | sort -u

dev:remarks.maml:para: Get hunt results based on a hunt id. Display all the unique file paths which were found with a file finder hunt. Only display the unique GRR client id's. then you can use `Get-GRRComputerNameByClientId` to display only the computer names.

maml:description.maml:para: Get all labels.
Get all labels.

maml:Description.maml:para: GRR credentials.
Return plain JSON instead of parsed JSON object.
GRR credentials.
Return plain JSON instead of parsed JSON object.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Return every label which is available in GRR.
Return every available label which contains "osx".

maml:description.maml:para: Return the headers and the websession for a specific GRR server.
Return the headers and the websession for a specific GRR server.
Used inside GRR requests to get the GRR session. Can be used manually in the console.

maml:Description.maml:para: GRR credentials.
GRR credentials.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Gets a new GRR session and obtains the headers and the CSRF token.

maml:description.maml:para: Invoke a flow on one or multiple clients.
Invoke a flow on one or multiple clients. The dynamic parameter "Flow" allows using dedicated parameters for each flow type.
Use the following dynamic parameters for each flow type (-Flow) to specifcy the needed values. Mandatory parameters are attributed with (m). - Netstat:
- FileFinder:

- Path (m), Type: String[] - ActionType (m), ValidateSet: Hash, Download - ConditionType, ValidateSet: Regex,Literal - Mode, ValidateSet: All_HITS, FIRST_HIT - SearchString, Type: String - RegistryFinder: - Key (m), Type: String[] - ConditionType, ValidateSet: Regex,Literal - Mode, ValidateSet: All_HITS, FIRST_HIT - ConditionValue, Type: String - ListProcesses: - FileNameRegex, Type: string - ExecutePythonHack: - HackName (m), Type: string - PyArgsName (m), Type: string - PyArgsValue (m), Type: string - ArtifactCollectorFlow: - ArtifactList (m), Type: String[] - YaraProcessScan: - YaraSignatureFile (m), Type: string

maml:Description.maml:para: ComputerName for the GRR flow. If multiple clients were found in GRR the last seen on client will be used for the flow.
GRR credentials.
Dynamic parameter "flow" allows specificing the desired flow type. Use the flow specific parameters to provide the needed information.
Email address for the output plugin. The count is set to 1 so your get en email if something is found.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Return only plain JSON instead of converted JSON objects.
ComputerName for the GRR flow. If multiple clients were found in GRR the last seen on client will be used for the flow.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
GRR credentials.
Email address for the output plugin. The count is set to 1 so your get en email if something is found.
Dynamic parameter "flow" allows specificing the desired flow type. Use the flow specific parameters to provide the needed information.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Return only plain JSON instead of converted JSON objects.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Invoke-GRRFlow -ComputerName host1 -Credential $cred -Flow FileFinder -path "C:\test.exe" -actiontype hash

dev:remarks.maml:para: Start a new file finder flow.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Invoke-GRRFlow -ComputerName host1 -Credential $cred -Flow FileFinder -path "C:\Files\*" -actiontype hash -ConditionType Literal -SearchString "GRR"

dev:remarks.maml:para: Start a new file finder flow and use the literal condition.

command:example.maml:title: Example 3
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Invoke-GRRFlow -ComputerName host1 -Credential $cred -Flow FileFinder -path "C:\Files\*" -actiontype hash -ConditionType Regex -SearchString ".*GRR.*"

dev:remarks.maml:para: Start a new file finder flow and use the regex condition.
Start a Yara scan on the specific host with the provided Yara rule.

maml:description.maml:para: Helper function for GRR requests. If a function you need is not available you can use this function to run the needed request.

Helper function for GRR requests. If a function you need is not available, you can use this function to run the needed request. The headers and websession are obtained by `Get-GRRSession` and only needed for POST requests.

GRR credentials.
Headers for the API requests (CSRF ...)

File if an upload is performed.

Return only plain JSON instead of converted JSON objects.

Headers for the API requests (CSRF ...)
Return only plain JSON instead of converted JSON objects.

File if an upload is performed.

Return only the approval id. Use that flag to be able to pipe that into a wait command.

Users which should be notified for the approval.
Return only the approval id. Use that flag to be able to pipe that into a wait command.
Reason for that approval.

Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> New-GRRClientApproval -Credential $cred -NotifiedUsers firstname.lastname -Reason "the reason for that approval" -OnlyId -ComputerName host

dev:remarks.maml:para: Creates a new approval for that specific host and notify the specified user.

maml:description.maml:para: Create a new hunt.

Flow types: - FileFinder: - Path (m), Type: String[] - ActionType (m), ValidateSet: Hash, Download - ConditionType, ValidateSet: Regex,Literal - Mode, ValidateSet: All_HITS, FIRST_HIT - SearchString, Type: String - RegistryFinder: - Key (m), Type: String[] - ListProcesses: - FileNameRegex, Type: string - ExecutePythonHack: - HackName (m), Type: string - PyArgsName (m), Type: string - PyArgsValue (m), Type: string - ArtifactCollectorFlow: - ArtifactList (m), Type: String[] - YaraProcessScan: - YaraSignatureFile (m), Type: string
Create a new hunt with the given flow properties.

maml:Description.maml:para: Hunt description.
Flow type for the hunt.
Rule type for the hunt.
Email address for the notification after the first result.
GRR credentials.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Return only the url to the web ui.
Return plain JSON instead of parsed JSON object.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Client limit number. 0 for all hosts, 100 for 100 hosts only.
Client rate for that hunt. 0 no limit, 500 means 500 hosts per minute. Test the possibilities for your environment. If the rate is set to high, performance issues will arise.
Return only the hunt id for post-processing (e.g. create an approval based on this hunt id directly).
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
GRR credentials.
Email address for the notification after the first result.
Flow type for the hunt.
Hunt description.
Return only the url to the web ui.
Rule type for the hunt.
Return plain JSON instead of parsed JSON object.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Client limit number. 0 for all hosts, 100 for 100 hosts only.
Client rate for that hunt. 0 no limit, 500 means 500 hosts per minute. Test the possibilities for your environment. If the rate is set to high, performance issues will arise.
Return only the hunt id for post-processing (e.g. create an approval based on this hunt id directly).

command:example.maml:title: Example 1
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> New-GRRHunt -Credential $cred -HuntDescription "Hunting for malicious launch agent" -Flow FileFinder -EmailAddress emailadress@for-notifications.tld -MatchMode MATCH_ALL -OnlyUrl -RuleType label -Label label1 -path "/Users/knockknock/Library/LaunchAgents/apple.evil.plist" -actiontype hash

dev:remarks.maml:para: Create a new hunt and show only the URL after creating the hunt.

maml:description.maml:para: Delete artifacts in GRR.
Delete artifacts in GRR.

maml:Description.maml:para: Name of artifact to delete.
GRR credential.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Return plain JSON instead of converted JSON.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Name of artifact to delete.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
GRR credential.
Return plain JSON instead of converted JSON.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Remove-GRRArtifact -Credential $cred -Artifact WindowsDNSNameServer
status ------ OK

dev:remarks.maml:para: Delete WindowsDNSNameServer artifact in GRR.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2
command:example.dev:code:
PS> Remove-GRRArtifact -Credential $cred -Artifact WindowsDNSNameServer,WindowsDNSNameServer2v WARNUNG: Skipping artifact 'WindowsDNSNameServer2v' because it is not defined in GRR.
status ------ OK

dev:remarks.maml:para: Delete WindowsDNSNameServer and WindowsDNSNameServer2v artifacts in GRR. A warning is returned because one of the given artifacts was not found in GRR.

maml:description.maml:para: Remove a label on a range of clients.
Remove a label on a range of clients.

maml:Description.maml:para: Computer name(s) for which the label must be set.
Label which must be set.
GRR credentials.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Return plain JSON instead of converted JSON.
Computer name(s) for which the label must be set.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
GRR credentials.
Label which must be set.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Return plain JSON instead of converted JSON.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Remove-GRRLabel -ComputerName host1, host2 -Label label1 -Credential $creds PS C:\> "host1", "host2" | Remove-GRRLabel -Label label1 -Credential $creds

dev:remarks.maml:para: Remove the label "label1" to both hosts. It's possible to use pipeline to remove the labels.
Use the GRR search to find specific clients on which both labels should be removed.

maml:description.maml:para: Set a label on one or multiple clients.
Set a label on one or multiple clients. The function has pipeline support.

maml:Description.maml:para: Computernames which should be labeled.
Label to set for the clients.
GRR credentials.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Return plain JSON instead of converted JSON.
Computernames which should be labeled.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
GRR credentials.
Label to set for the clients.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Return plain JSON instead of converted JSON.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Set-GRRLabel -ComputerName host1, host2 -Label label1 -Credential $creds PS C:\> "host1", "host2" | Set-GRRLabel -Label label1 -Credential $creds

dev:remarks.maml:para: Add the label "label1" to both hosts. It's possible to use pipeline to set the labels.
Use the GRR search to find specific clients which should be labeled.

maml:description.maml:para: Start a GRR hunt based on the hunt id.
Start a GRR hunt based on the hunt id.

maml:Description.maml:para: HuntId of the hunt which should be started.
GRR credentials.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Show plain JSON as output instead of the return object.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Approval id to wait for.
Timeout for the wait.
Wait until the given approval gets valid.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
GRR credentials.
HuntId of the hunt which should be started.
Show plain JSON as output instead of the return object.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Approval id to wait for.
Timeout for the wait.
Wait until the given approval gets valid.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Start the specific hunt. Approval must be granted before.
Start the specific hunt and wait until given approval gets valid.

command:example.maml:title: Example 3
command:example.dev:code: Start-GRRHunt -Credential $cred -HuntId $hunt -Wait -ApprovalId (New-GRRHuntApproval -Credential $cred -HuntId $hunt -NotifiedUsers user.name -Reason "Reason for that hunt approval" -OnlyId)

dev:remarks.maml:para: Start the specific hunt and wait until given approval gets valid. Use both commands, the start and the approval in on command.

maml:description.maml:para: Stop a hunt.
Stop a hunt.

GRR credentials.

Wait for the given client approval gets valid.
